title: Consumer and producer surplus
description: Many times, the equilibrium price is lower than the highest price some folks are willing to pay.  For all consumers, this is called consumer surplus.  Similarly, the price might be higher than the minimum price at which some are willing to produce.  For all the producers, this is called producer surplus.  This tutorial covers them both with an emphasis on the visual.

items.title: Demand Curve as Marginal Benefit Curve
items.description: Thinking about a demand curve in terms of quantity driving price

items.title: Consumer Surplus Introduction
items.description: Consumer surplus as difference between marginal benefit and price paid

items.title: Total Consumer Surplus as Area
items.description: Looking at consumer surplus as area between the demand curve and the market price

items.title: Producer Surplus
items.description: Looking at the supply curve as an opportunity cost curve.  Understanding the producer surplus as the area between the supply curve and the market price

title: Deadweight loss
description: We can often lose economic efficiency because of things like price floors, ceilings and taxes.  This loss in surplus (people who have more marginal benefit than marginal cost are not buying or people who have more marginal cost than benefit are buying) is called deadweight loss.

items.title: Rent Control and Deadweight Loss
items.description: How instituting a price ceiling lower than the equilibrium price reduces the total surplus (dead weight loss)

items.title: Minimum Wage and Price Floors
items.description: How a minimum wage might effect the labor market

items.title: Taxation and Dead Weight Loss
items.description: The effect of taxation on the equilibrium price and quantity

items.title: Percentage Tax on Hamburgers
items.description: What would happen if we have a percentage tax instead of a fixed dollar amount

items.title: Taxes and Perfectly Inelastic Demand
items.description: Who bears the burden for the taxes when demand is inelastic

items.title: Taxes and Perfectly Elastic Demand
items.description: Who bears the burden for a tax on a good with perfectly elastic demand

title: Public goods and externalities
description: In many scenarios thinking only about producers' marginal cost or consumers' marginal benefit does not fully capture *all* of the costs or benefits from the production/use of a product.  In this tutorial, we explore these externalities (negative and positive ones) to think a bit deeper about ways to maximize total surplus not just for producers and consumers, but for society as a whole.

items.title: Negative Externalities
items.description: Taking negative externalities into account when thinking about the optimal equilibrium price and quantity

items.title: Taxes for Factoring in Negative Externalities
items.description: How to factor in negative externalities through taxation

items.title: Positive Externalities
items.description: Factoring in external benefits

items.title: Tragedy of the Commons
items.description: How public resources can be abused

title: Scarcity, possibilities, preferences and opportunity cost
description: How do you decide what to produce or trade?  How can you maximize happiness in a world of scarcity.  What are you giving up when you choose something (i.e., opportunity cost)?

title: Production possibilities frontier
description: This tutorial goes back to the basics.  You are a hunter-gatherer with only so much time to hunt or gather.  How do you allocate your time and energy to maximize you happiness?  This is what we try to understand through our study of the production possibilities frontier and opportunity cost.

items.title: Production Possibilities Frontier
items.description: Tradeoffs for a hunter gatherer and the production possibilities frontier.  Ceteris Paribus

items.title: Opportunity Cost
items.description: Opportunity cost (and marginal cost) based on the PPF

items.title: Increasing Opportunity Cost
items.description: Why the opportunity cost may increase as you pursue more rabbits

items.title: Allocative Efficiency and Marginal Benefit
items.description: Marginal Utility and maximization

items.title: Economic Growth through Investment
items.description: How investing for capital formation can expand the production possibilities frontier (PPF)

title: Comparative advantage and gains from trade
description:
Should you try to produce everything yourself or only what you are best at and trade for everything else?  What if you're better than your trading partners at everything?  

This tutorial focuses on comparative advantage, specialization and gains from trade with a microeconomic lens.

items.title: Comparative Advantage Specialization and Gains from Trade
items.description: How two parties can get better outcomes by specializing in their comparative advantage and trading

items.title: Comparative Advantage and Absolute Advantage
items.description: Showing that a party benefits from trade as long as there is a comparative advantage (and not necessarily an absolute advantage)

title: Marginal utility and budget lines
description: In this tutorial we look at the utility of getting one more of something and put numbers to it.  We then use this to construct a budget line and think about indifference curves.

items.title: Marginal Utility
items.description: Marginal utility and marginal benefit.  How you would spend $5 on chocolate and fruit

items.title: Equalizing Marginal Utility per Dollar Spent
items.description: Why the marginal utility for dollar spent should be theoritically equal for the last increment of either good purchased

items.title: Deriving Demand Curve from Tweaking Marginal Utility per Dollar
items.description: Seeing what happens to quantity demanded when price changes

items.title: Budget Line
items.description: What I can buy with my income

items.title: Indifference Curves and Marginal Rate of Substitution
Optimal Point on Budget Line
items.description: Using indifference curves to think about the point on the budget line that maximizes total utility

items.title: Types of Indifference Curves
items.description: Indifference curves for normal goods, substitutes and perfect complements

title: Production decisions and economic profit
description: Economic profit vs. accounting profit.  Average total cost (ATC) and marginal cost (MC).  Marginal product of labor (MPL).  Price discrimination.

title: Economic profit and opportunity cost
description: Economic profit and accounting profit are two different things (the difference being that economic profit takes into account opportunity cost).  Confused?  This tutorial lays it all out with the example of a restaurant.

items.title: Economic Profit vs Accounting Profit
items.description: Difference between a firm's accounting and economic profit

items.title: Depreciation and Opportunity Cost of Capital
items.description: How to account for things when you own the building instead of renting it

title: Average costs (ATC, MC) and marginal revenue (MR)
description: In this tutorial, Sal uses the example of an orange juice business to help us understand the ideas of average total cost (ATC), marginal cost (MC) and marginal revenue (MR).  We then use this understanding to answer the age-old question, "how much orange juice should I produce?"  Finally, we use these ideas to construct a long-run supply curve.  A must watch if you're interested in making juice!

items.title: Marginal Cost and Average Total Cost
items.description: Looking at marginal and average total cost in the context of a juice business

items.title: Marginal Revenue and Marginal Cost
items.description: Thinking about a rational quantity of juice to produce

items.title: Marginal Revenue Below Average Total Cost
items.description: Why it is rational to produce at a loss

items.title: Long Term Supply Curve and Economic Profit
items.description: Understanding the long term supply curve in terms of economic profit

title: Average fixed, variable and marginal costs
description: Using a spreadsheet, Sal walks through an example of average costs per line of code as a firm hires more engineers.  Really good primer to understand what average fixed costs, average variable costs, average total costs (ATC) and average marginal costs (MC) are (and how they are calculated).

items.title: Fixed, Variable, and Marginal Cost.
items.description: Thinking about average fixed, variable and marginal cost

items.title: Visualizing Average Costs and Marginal Costs as Slope
items.description: Graphing variable cost, fixed cost and total cost

title: Labor and marginal product revenue
description: Constructing a demand curve for an individual firm by thinking about how much increment benefit they get from an incremental employee (marginal product of labor (MPL) and marginal product revenue (MPR).  We later think about how we can add these "demand" curves to construct a "demand" curve for the market for labor in this industry.

items.title: A Firm's Marginal Product Revenue Curve
items.description: Thinking about how much incremental benefit a firm gets from hiring one more person

items.title: How Many People to Hire Given the MPR curve
items.description: Thinking about how many people it makes sense to hire.  Brief discussion of a monopsony.

items.title: Adding Demand Curves
items.description: How to add demand curves

title: Price discrimination
description: This short tutorial explores how a wine business can utilize first-degree price discrimination to maximize economic profit (it uses many of the ideas we've explored in the rest of this tutorial).

items.title: First Degree Price Discrimination
items.description: Charging different consumers different amounts in an attempt to optimize economic profit

title: Perfect competition
description: This tutorial looks at markets that are deemed to have "perfect competition."  This means that there are many players with identical products, no barriers to entry, no advantage for existing players and good pricing information.  Few to no real market completely matches this theoretical ideal, but many are close.  Even the example we use in this tutorial (the airline industry) isn't quite perfect (you should think about why).

items.title: Perfect Competition
items.description: Conditions for perfect competition.  Looking at the airline industry

title: Monopoly
description:
No, we aren't talking about the board game although the game does try to approximate what this tutorial is about--notice that you can charge more rent at either Boardwalk or Park Place if you own both (you have a "monopoly" in the navy blue market).

The opposite of perfect competition is when you have only one firm operating.  This tutorial explores what this firm would do to maximize economic profit.

items.title: Monopoly Basics
items.description: Thinking about what would happen with one airline.  The opposite of perfect competition

items.title: Monopolist Optimizing Price (part 1)- Total Revenue.
items.description: Starting to think about how a monopolist would rationally optimize profits

items.title: Monopolist Optimizing Price (part 2)- Marginal Revenue
items.description: Plotting the marginal revenue curve for a monopolist

items.title: Monopolist Optimizing Price (part 3)- Dead Weight Loss.avi
items.description: Showing that what is optimal for the monopolist is not optimal for society

items.title: Optional Calculus Proof to Show that MR has Twice Slope of Demand
items.description: Using some basic calculus to show that marginal revenue has twice the slope of the demand curve for a monopolist

items.title: Review of Revenue and Cost Graphs for a Monopoly

title: Between perfect competition and monopoly
description: Most markets sit somewhere in-between perfect competition and monopolies.  This tutorial explores some of those scenarios--from monopolistic competition to oligopolies and duopolies.

items.title: Oligopolies and Monopolistic Competition
items.description: Thinking about different markets that are in-between monopolies and perfect competition

items.title: Monopolistic Competition and Economic Profit
items.description: Why it is hard for a monopolisitc competitor to make economic profit in the long run

items.title: Oligopolies, Duopolies, Collusion, and Cartels
items.description: Thinking about when oligopolies behave more like monopolies or perfect competitors

title: Nash equilibrium
description:
If you haven't watched the movie "A Beautiful Mind", you should.  It is about John Nash (played by Russell Crowe) who won the Nobel Prize in economics for his foundational contributions to game theory.  This is what this tutorial is about.

Nash put some structure around how players in a "game" can optimize their outcomes (if the movie is to be fully believed, this insight struck him when he realize that if all his friends hit on the most pretty girl, he should hit on the second-most pretty one).  In this tutorial, we use the classic "prisoner's dilemma" to highlight this concept.

items.title: Prisoners' Dilemma and Nash Equilibrium
items.description: Why two not-so-loyal criminals would want to snitch each other out

items.title: More on Nash Equilibrium
items.description: Looking more closely at the definition of Nash Equilibrium

title: Why parties in a cartel will cheat
description:
You know what Nash equilibrium is (from the other tutorial).  Now we apply it to a scenario that is fairly realistic--parties to a cartel cheating.

A cartel is a group of actors that agree (sometimes illegally) to coordinate their production/pricing to maximize their collective economic profit.  What we will see, however, is that this is not a "Pareto optimal" state and they will soon start producing more than agreed on.

items.title: Why Parties to Cartels Cheat
items.description: Why duopolists would benefit to form a cartel and why it makes sense for them to cheat

items.title: Game Theory of Cheating Firms
items.description: Pareto Optimality and more on Nash Equilibrium.  Seeing how cheating duopolists parallels the prisoners dilemma

title: Macroeconomics
description: Topics covered in a traditional college level introductory macroeconomics course

title: GDP - measuring national income
description: Circular flow of income and expenditure.  Gross domestic product.

title: Introduction to economics
description: This very short tutorial gives us the big picture of what economics is all about and, in particular, compares macroeconomics (where you are now) to microeconomics.

title: GDP and the circular flow of income and expenditures
description:
Economics can some times get confusing because one person's expenditure is another person's income which can then be used for expenditure and on and on and on.  Seems very circular.  It is.

This tutorial helps us grapple with this and introduces us to the primary tool economists use to measure a nations productivity/income/expenditure--GDP (gross domestic product).

items.title: Circular Flow of Income and Expenditures
items.description: Understanding the flow of resources in the simplest possible economy

items.title: Parsing Gross Domestic Product
items.description: Understanding what GDP does and doesn't measure.

items.title: More on Final and Intermediate GDP Contributions
items.description: What happens when a good is not finished in a period

title: Components of GDP
description: You already understand the circular nature of the economy and how GDP is defined from the last tutorial.  Now let's think about how economists define the composition of GDP.  In particular, we'll focus on consumption (C), investment (I), government spending (G) and net exports.

items.title: Investment and Consumption
items.description: Difference between every day and economic notions of investment and consumption

items.title: Income and Expenditure Views of GDP
items.description: Looking at a simple model of an economy

items.title: Components of GDP
items.description: Understanding the components of the expenditure view of GDP.  Consumption, investment, government spending and net exports

items.title: Examples of Accounting for GDP
items.description: Thinking about how different types of expenditures would be accounted for in GDP

title: Real and nominal GDP
description: The value of a currency is constantly changing (usually going down in terms of what you can buy).  Given this, how can we compare GDP measured in dollars in one year to another year? This tutorial answers that question by introducing you to real GDP and GDP deflators.

items.title: Real GDP and Nominal GDP
items.description: Using real GDP as a measure of actual productivity growth

items.title: GDP Deflator
items.description: Relationship between the GDP deflator, nominal GDP and real GDP

items.title: Example Calculating Real GDP with a Deflator
items.description: Simple example of calculating Real GDP from Nominal GDP

title: Inflation - measuring the cost of living
description: Inflation and deflation.  CPI-U. Real and nominal return.  Phillips Curve.

title: Measuring cost of living --inflation and the consumer price index
description: We might generally sense that our cost of living is going up (inflation), but how can we measure it?  This tutorial shows how it is done in the United States with the consumer price index (CPI).

items.title: Introduction to Inflation
items.description: Basics of price inflation and the CPI (consumer price index)

items.title: Actual CPI-U Basket of Goods
items.description: Exploring the actual weightings for the CPI-U basket of goods

title: Real and nominal return
description: We think we're getting a certain return on our investments, but can we put it in terms of real purchasing power since the value of money is constantly changing?  The answer is yes and this tutorial shows you how.

title: Deflation
description: Prices don't always go up.  Sometimes they go down (we call this deflation).  This tutorial explains how this happens.

title: Inflationary and deflationary scenarios
description: This tutorial walks through various scenarios of moderate and extreme price changes.  Very good way to understand how activity in the economy may impact price (and vice versa).

title: The Phillips Curve - Inflation and unemployment
description: Economists have notices a correlation between unemployment and correlation (you may wan to guess what type of correlation).  On some level, this tutorial is common sense, but it will give you fancy labels for this relation so that you can sound fancy at fancy parties.

items.title: Phillips Curve
items.description: The observation that inflation and unemployment tend to be inversely correlated

title: Aggregate demand and aggregate supply
description: Aggregate demand and aggregate supply. Keynesian thinking. Demand-pull and cost-push inflation.  Fiscal and monetary policy.

title: Aggregate demand and aggregate supply
description: This tutorial looks at supply and demand in aggregate-from the perspective of the entire economy (not just the market for one good or service).  Instead of thinking of quantity of one good, we think of total output (GDP).  Very useful model for thinking through macroeconomic events.

items.title: Aggregate Demand
items.description: Understanding how aggregate demand is different from demand for a specific good or service.  Justifications for the aggregate demand curve being downward sloping

items.title: Shifts in Aggregate Demand
items.description: Factors that might shift aggregate demand

items.title: Long-Run Aggregate Supply
items.description: Thinking about why aggregate supply may not be influenced by prices in the long-run

items.title: Short Run Aggregate Supply
items.description: Justifications for the aggregate supply curve to be upward sloping in the short-run

title: Historical circumstances explained by AD/AS
description: In the last tutorial, we claimed that the aggregate demand and aggregate supply model (AD-AS) would be useful for analyzing macroeconomic events.  Well, in this tutorial, we'll do exactly that.

items.title: Demand-Pull Inflation under Johnson
items.description: Thinking about whether inflation in the late 1960s is consistent with the AD-AS model

items.title: Real GDP driving Price
items.description: Thinking about how high utilization could drive price as another justification for an upward sloping short-run aggregate supply curve

items.title: Cost Push Inflation
items.description: How an oil shock can slow the economy while causing inflation

title: The business cycle
description: Economies never have a long steady march upwards.  They constantly oscillate between growth and recession.  This tutorial gives a little intuition for why that is.

items.title: The Business Cycle
items.description: The business cycle and how it may be driven by emotion

title: Monetary and fiscal policy
description: Governments (and pseudo government entities like central banks) have two tools at their disposal to try to impact the business cycle --monetary and fiscal policy.  This will help you understand what they are.

items.title: Monetary and Fiscal Policy
items.description: Basic mechanics of monetary and fiscal policy

items.title: Tax Lever of Fiscal Policy
items.description: How government can effect aggregate demand through tax policy

title: Keynesian thinking
description: Whether you love him or hate him (or just consider him a friend that you respect but disagree with every-now-and-then), Keynes has helped define how many modern governments think about their economies.  This tutorial explains how his thinking was a fundamental departure from classical economics.

items.title: Keynesian Economics
items.description: Contrasting Keynesian and Classical Thinking

items.title: Risks of Keynesian Thinking
items.description: Why Keynesian thinking might not be ideal sometimes

title: The monetary system
description: Fractional reserve banking and the money supply.

title: Fractional reserve banking
description:
Most modern economies use a counter-intuitive model of banking called "fractional reserve banking."  It is counter-intuitive (and some people would say wrong) because it allows banks to lend out money that it tells depositors is available at any time and essentially involves private banks in money creation.  It also creates the possibility of mass instability through bank runs that tend to be mitigated through government regulation and insurance (some would say government subsidy of banks).

This tutorial explains how fractional reserve lending works and outlines the good and bad.  It also talks about the alternative of full reserve banking.

items.title: Overview of Fractional Reserve Banking
items.description: Big picture of how money enters circulation and how lending can increase the money supply

items.title: Weaknesses of Fractional Reserve Lending
items.description: Weaknesses of Fractional Reserve Lending

items.title: Full Reserve Banking
items.description: Overview of full reserve banking in comparison to fractional reserve banking

title: Money supply
description: This short tutorial explains how we measure how much "money" there is out there.  As we'll see, this isn't as straightforward as counting dollars in people's pockets, especially because there are multiple type of money.

items.title: Money Supply- M0 M1 and M2
items.description: Different ways of measuring the money supply

title: Fractional reserve accounting
description: If you already know a bit of what fractional reserve banking involves, this tutorial will take you deeper by looking at the actual accounting of central banks and banks.

items.title: Simple Fractional Reserve Accounting (part 2)
items.description: How banks can actually create checking accounts under a fractional reserve system

title: Interest as the price of money

items.title: Interest as Rent for Money
items.description: Thinking about interest as the price of money.  Looking at money from a supply and demand perspective

items.title: Money Supply and Demand Impacting Interest Rates
items.description: Examples showing how various factors can affect interest rates

title: Income and expenditure - Keynesian cross and IS-LM model
description: Consumption function.  Marginal propensity to consume and multiplier.  Keynesian Cross and IS-LM model.

title: Marginal propensity to consume (MPC)
description:
If you earn a $1, you might spend some fraction of it.  This can then be income for someone else.  This can keep going.  

In this tutorial, we'll explore how the incremental spend per incremental earnings  (marginal propensity to consume) and the multiplier effect based on it can drive economic activity.

items.title: MPC and Multiplier
items.description: Introduction to the marginal propensity to consume and the multiplier

items.title: Mathy Version of MPC and Multiplier (optional)
items.description: Generalizing what we did in the last video with more math

title: Consumption function
description: We are steadily building up the tools to understand the Keynesian Cross and the IS-LM model.  In this tutorial, we begin to model consumption as a linear function of disposable income.  Seems reasonable to me.

items.title: Consumption Function Basics
items.description: The basic idea of a consumption function

items.title: Generalized Linear Consumption Function
items.description: Generalizing a linear consumption function as a function of aggregate income

items.title: Consumption Function with Income Dependent Taxes
items.description: Thinking about a consumption function where taxes are also a function of income (which is more realistic than constant taxes)

title: Keynesian Cross
description: We now build on our consumption function models and start to explore ideas of planned expenditures as a function of output.  When plotted with the actual output line, we get our Keynesian Cross which helps us think about whether the economy is operating at its potential.

items.title: Keynesian Cross
items.description: Analyzing planned expenditures versus actual output using the Keynesian Cross

items.title: Details on Shifting Aggregate Planned Expenditures
items.description: Showing how a change in government spending can lead to a new equilibrium

items.title: Keynesian Cross and the Multiplier
items.description: More on shifting aggregate planned expenditures.  Connecting to the multiplier

title: IS-LM Model
description:
In this tutorial, we begin thinking about the impact of real interest rates on planned investment and output.  We then use this to help us plot the IS curve.  We then think about how, assuming a fixed money supply, as there is more economic activity, people are willing to pay more for money (helps us plot the LM curve).  Finally, we use the IS-LM model to think about how fiscal policy can impact both GDP and real interest rates.

You should watch the Keynesian Cross tutorial before this one.

items.title: Investment and Real Interest Rates
items.description: Intuition as to why high real interest rates lead to low investment and why low rates lead to high investment

items.title: Connecting the Keynesian Cross to the IS-Curve
items.description: Introduction to the Investment/Savings curve

items.title: Loanable Funds Interpretation of IS Curve
items.description: Thinking about how real GDP can drive real interest rates

items.title: LM part of the IS-LM model
items.description: How the theory of liquidity preference drives demand for money and the LM (liquidity preference-money supply) curve

items.title: Government Spending and the IS-LM model
items.description: How a change in fiscal policy shifts the IS curve

title: Foreign exchange and trade
description: Balance of payments.  Current account.  Capital account.  Currency reserves and speculative attacks.

title: Balance of payments- current account and capital account
description: In this tutorial we will see how trade and assets (including money) changing hands are fundamentally intertwined.  Not only that, but we will see how this can be accounted for through the capital account (assets changing hands) and current account (trade).

items.title: Balance of Payments- Current Account
items.description: Understanding the United States Current Account in 2011

items.title: Balance of Payments- Capital Account
items.description: Understanding how changes in foreign ownership of assets effects balance of payments

items.title: Why Current and Capital Accounts Net Out
items.description: Intuition behind why the current account and capital account should balance

title: Currency reserves
description: This tutorial delves into how and why countries (usually their central banks) would want to keep other countries' currency in reserve.  It then goes into why this sometime leaves the reserve-holding country open to a speculative attack (this is seriously high drama).

items.title: Accumulating Foreign Currency Reserves
items.description: How and why a central bank would build foreign currency reserves

items.title: Using Reserves to Stabilize Currency
items.description: How a central bank could use foreign currency reserves to keep its own currency from devaluing

title: Computer science
description: Introduction to programming and computer science

items.title: Introduction to Programs Data Types and Variables
items.description: Writing a basic program.  Basics of data types, variables and conditional statements

items.title: Binary Numbers
items.description: Understanding how numbers are represented.  Introduction to binary numbers

items.title: Python Lists
items.description: Understanding the basics of lists in Python

items.title: For Loops in Python
items.description: Basics of for loops in Python

items.title: While Loops in Python
items.description: Seeing that a while loop can do the same thing as a for loop

items.title: Fun with Strings
items.description: Experimenting and seeing what we can do with strings

items.title: Writing a Simple Factorial Program. (Python 2)
items.description: Writing a simple factorial program with a "for" loop

items.title: Stepping Through the Factorial Program
items.description: Stepping through what happens when a user inputs a particular value into our factorial program

items.title: Flowchart for the Factorial Program
items.description: Flowchart  for the factorial program

items.title: Python 3 Not Backwards Compatible with Python 2
items.description: Understanding why the example program would not run in Python 3 and how to fix it.

items.title: Defining a Factorial Function
items.description: Defining a function in Python

items.title: Diagramming What Happens with a Function Call
items.description: Variable scope and function calls

items.title: Recursive Factorial Function
items.description: Introduction to recursion.

items.title: Comparing Iterative and Recursive Factorial Functions
items.description: Comparing iterative and recursive factorial functions

items.title: Iterative Fibonacci Function Example
items.description: One way to write a Fibonacci function iteratively

items.title: Stepping Through Iterative Fibonacci Function
items.description: Understanding how the iterative fibonacci function works for a particular example

items.title: Recursive Fibonacci Example
items.description: Using recursion to write a fibonacci function

items.title: Stepping Through Recursive Fibonacci Function
items.description: Understanding why and how the recursive Fibonacci function works

items.title: Exercise - Write a Sorting Function
items.description: Challenge to write a Python function that can sort a list in-place

items.title: Insertion Sort Algorithm
items.description: Visual description of the insertion sort algorithm

items.title: Insertion Sort in Python
items.description: Basic implementation of insertion sort algorithm

items.description: Clarifying what "break" does and stepping through the insertion sort implementation

items.description: Simplifying the while loop for the Insertion Sort function

title: Healthcare and medicine
description:
Videos about medicine and the healthcare system.  These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have
regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.

items.title: What is the flu?
items.description:
Learn the difference between the cold and the flu, and how we sometimes can get fooled by viruses!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

These videos do not provide medical advice and are for informational purposes only. The videos are not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of a qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay in seeking it because of something you have read or seen in any Khan Academy video.

items.title: Testing for the Flu
items.description:
Learn when testing for influenza makes sense, and the most common test that is used.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: 5 Common Flu Vaccine Excuses
items.description:
Many people choose to avoid the flu vaccine each year.  Review five popular excuses, and how they relate to common misunderstandings about the flu.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood
description: Find out what's inside of blood

items.title: What's Inside of Blood?
items.description: Spin down your blood and find out what it's made up of.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Hemoglobin moves O2 and CO2
items.description: Learn the two ways that oxygen moves from the lungs to the tissues, and the three ways that carbon dioxide returns from the tissues to the lungs.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Bohr Effect vs. Haldane Effect
items.description: Take a close look at how some friendly competition for Hemoglobin allows the body to more efficiently move oxygen and carbon Dioxide around.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Fetal Hemoglobin and Hematocrit
items.description: Although mom controls the oxygen source, the fetus has a couple of clever tricks to get the most oxygen possible!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Oxygen Content
items.description: Learn how oxygen content (CaO2) is related to Hemoglobin concentration (Hb), oxygen saturation (SaO2), and the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2).  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood Pressure
description: Learn about blood pressure and how we measure it.  Take a deeper dive and find out how blood pressure is related to resistance and flow!

items.title: What is blood pressure?
items.description: Find out what a systolic and diastolic blood pressure mean.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Learn how a stethoscope can help determine blood pressure
items.description: Learn how Dr. Korotkoff cleverly used a stethoscope to determine blood pressure, and that we still use his trick today!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Resistance in a tube
items.description: Learn how the size of a tube (it's radius) is related to its resistance to something flowing through.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Adding up resistance in series and in parallel
items.description: Learn about how resistance can be added up in series and in parallel (similar to electrical circuits!).   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Adding up resistance problem
items.description: Here's a chance to see if you can combine what you know to add up resistance in series AND in parallel.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Flow and Perfusion
items.description: Learn the difference between blood flow (Volume/time) and perfusion (Volume/time/amount of tissue).  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Putting it all together: Pressure, flow, and resistance
items.description: See how pressure, flow, and resistance relate to one another and how they each affect the human body.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Blood pressure changes over time
items.description: See how increasing resistance in the blood vessels can cause blood pressure to rise over time.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood Vessel Diseases
description: Learn about how arteries differ from veins and how arteries can get damaged over time.

items.title: Arteries vs. Veins - What's the difference?
items.description: Learn some important differences between arteries (high pressure/low volume) and veins (low pressure/high volume).  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Layers of a blood vessel
items.description: Remember the 3 key layers of a blood vessel (Tunica intima, Tunica media, and Tunica externa) and how arteries, veins, and capillaries are all different from one another.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Arteriosclerosis, Arteriolosclerosis, and Atherosclerosis
items.description: Learn the difference between Arteriosclerosis, Arteriolosclerosis, and Atherosclerosis!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Atherosclerosis - Part 1
items.description: See how Atherosclerosis (Fat in the blood vessel wall) hardens the arterial wall and makes it harder for blood to flow through.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Atherosclerosis - Part 2
items.description: See how Atherosclerosis (Fat in the blood vessel wall) hardens the arterial wall and makes it harder for blood to flow through.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Arteriolosclerosis - Part 1
items.description: See how hyaline arteriolosclerosis (Protein in the arterial wall) causes hardening of the blood vessels.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Arteriolosclerosis - Part 2
items.description: See how hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (Protein in the arterial wall) makes it difficult for blood to go through blood vessels.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Blood Pressure Control
description: Find out how the body works to maintain a normal blood pressure by sensing when its too high or too low and responding accordingly.

items.title: Regulation of blood pressure with baroreceptors
items.description: Learn about how the arteries use nerve impulses to help regulate blood pressure.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Parts of a nephron
items.description: Learn about the 5 major parts of the kidney's nephron.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: General overview of the RAAS system - Cells and hormones
items.description: Learn the important cells and hormones that are working together to control your blood pressure!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Renin production in the kidneys
items.description: Learn the three major triggers for Renin production by the Juxtaglomerular cells.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Activating Angiotensin 2
items.description: See how Renin and ACE work to cut Angiotensinogen down to size!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Angiotensin 2 raises blood pressure
items.description: See how Angiotensin 2 effects 4 target "organs" to increase blood pressure.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Aldosterone raises blood pressure and lowers potassium
items.description: See how Aldosterone effects the principal cells of the kidney to raise BP and lower potassium.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Aldosterone removes acid from the blood
items.description: See how Aldosterone acts on the alpha-intercalated cell to remove protons (acid) from the blood.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: ADH secretion
items.description: Learn the key triggers for ADH secretion.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: ADH effects on blood pressure
items.description: See how ADH acts on blood vessels and the kidney to raise blood pressure.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Aldosterone and ADH
items.description: Find out how Aldosterone and ADH cause changes in volume and osmolarity.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Fetal Circulation
description: Find out how the heart and circulatory system work in the fetus!

items.title: Meet the Placenta!
items.description: Learn how the needs of the fetus are met by the placenta, which is a special organ that belongs to both the mother and the fetus!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Umbilical vessels and the Ductus Venosus
items.description: Watch as fetal blood goes through umbilical vessels and takes a shortcut through the Ductus Venosus to make it back to the heart.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Flow through the Heart
items.description: Learn how blood flows through the heart, and understand the difference between systemic and pulmonary blood flow.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction
items.description: Watch how blood gets diverted away from alveoli with low oxygen levels.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Foramen Ovale and Ductus Arteriosus
items.description: Watch how the fetal heart allows blood to simply bypass the lungs altogether using the Foramen Ovale and the Ductus Arteriosus!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Double Bohr Effect
items.description: Learn how there are two distinct Bohr effects happening at the same time in the placenta.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Fetal Circulation Right Before Birth
items.description: Watch how the blood flows through the fetal circulation and compare it to what happens in the baby's body.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Baby Circulation Right After Birth
items.description: Watch how the blood flows through the baby's circulation and compare it to what happens in the fetus. Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Fetal Structures in an Adult
items.description: Find out what happens to those nifty fetal structures once we get older.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Arterial Stiffness
description: Find out why having "stiff arteries" can increase blood pressure and cause uneven blood flow.  It all comes back to the idea of "total energy"!

items.title: Compliance and Elastance
items.description: Learn about compliance (and elastance) of arteries, veins, and lead pipes!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Bernoulli's equation of total energy
items.description: Learn how total energy of a fluid helps explain why fluids can move from low pressure to high pressure!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Stored elastic energy in large and middle sized arteries
items.description: See how arteries behave like sling shots, shooting blood (not rocks) onwards!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Compliance - Decreased blood pressure
items.description: Find out how compliance allows arteries to store elastic energy (and lower pressure).   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Compliance - Increased blood flow
items.description: Learn how compliant arteries allows for a "Constant Pressure System" like a modern water gun!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Healthy Lifestyle
description: Learn some of the fundamentals behind staying healthy: Reducing your salt, keeping your weight in a healthy range, and exercising regularly.

items.title: Low salt diet
items.description: Figure out the difference between "salt" and "sodium" and how much salt is recommended on a low sodium diet.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Spotting salty foods
items.description: Find out how much sodium is in some common foods and how you can maintain a low sodium diet.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Calculate your own Body Mass Index
items.description: Find out how simple it is to calculate your BMI and the common BMI categories.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Introduction to exercise
items.description: Learn the three fundamental categories of exercise and how you can incorporate exercise recommendations into a workout.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: 11 major muscle groups
items.description: This quick video goes over 11 major muscle groups in the body.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Endocrinology and Diabetes
description: Learn about hormones and diabetes, as well as some important information on glucose control.

items.title: Intro to the Endocrine System
items.description: Basic overview of hormones and the endocrine system

items.title: Precocious Puberty
items.description: At Stanford Medical School with Morgan Theis talking to  Dr. Laura Bachrach talking about precocious puberty

items.title: Childhood Growth
items.description: Sal talks with Dr. Laura Bachrach about childhood growth

items.title: Glucose Insulin and Diabetes
items.description: The basics of Type I and Type II diabetes

items.title: Blood Sugar Levels
items.description: Normal and elevated blood sugar levels before (preprandia) and after (postprandial) a meal

items.title: A1C Levels
items.description: Why measuring Hemoglobin A1c levels is an indicator of blood sugar levels (and diabetes)

title: Health Care System
description: Learn some basics about the Health Care system in the US

items.title: Blue Cross and Blue Shield
items.description: Sal and Dr. Baker talk a bit about Blue Cross and Blue Shield

items.title: Conversation About Drug Pricing
items.description: Dr. Lauwrence Baker talks to Sal about how drug prices are set

items.title: Health Care Costs in US vs Europe
items.description: A discussion about US health care costs

items.title: Healthcare System Overview
items.description: The different roles in the healthcare system

items.title: Paying Doctors
items.description: Basics of how doctors get paid

items.title: Medicare Overview
items.description: Sal talks with Professor Laurence Baker of Stanford Medical School

title: Colon Disease
description: Get a ring-side seat as a pathologist talks about colon cells under the microscope.

items.title: Normal Colon Tissue
items.description: Dr. Andy Connolly from Stanford Medical School introduces Sal to what normal colon tissue looks like

items.title: Hyperplasia in Colon Tissue
items.description: Dr. Andy Connolly from Stanford Medical School shows Sal what hyperplasia in colon tissue looks like

items.title: Colon Dysplasia
items.description: Dr. Andy Connolly shows Sal what cancerous colon tissue looks like

items.title: Cancerous Colon Tissue
items.description: Dr. Andy Connolly of Stanford Medical School shows us what cancerous colon tissue looks like

title: Cervical Spine
description: Learn about the cervical (neck) spine through an Xray!

items.title: Adequacy of the Lateral Cervical Spine X-Ray
items.description: Dr. Mahadevan from Stanford School of Medicine explains adequacy for lateral cervical (neck) x-rays

items.title: Assessing Alignment of the Lateral Cervical Spine (neck) X-Ray
items.description: Dr. Mahadevan of Stanford Medical School shows Sal what misalignment in the neck could look like in an X-ray

items.title: Cervical Spine Protection in Airway Management (not a substitute for formal training)
items.description: Cervical Spine Protection in Airway Management.  This is for education only.  It is not a substitute for formal training or licensure.  Every effort has been made in preparing this video to provide accurate and up-to-date information which is in accord accepted standards and practice at the time of production.  We make no warranties on the information contained in the video because clinical standards are constantly changing through research and regulation.  We disclaim all liability for direct or consequential damages resulting from the use of material contained in this video.

title: The Lungs
description: Get a better understanding of how your lungs help you to sing and survive!

items.title: Meet the lungs
items.description: Every time you take a breath, oxygen makes it way into your lungs.  Follow along on that journey!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: People and plants
items.description: Learn more about photosynthesis and cellular respiration through a classic story: Jack and the Beanstalk.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: The Bronchial Tree
items.description: Follow the path of an oxygen molecule as it makes its way from your mouth down to an alveolus!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Inhaling and Exhaling
items.description: Find out exactly why air goes in and out of the lungs.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: How does Lung Volume Change?
items.description: Learn about how muscle contraction and lung recoil actually help the lungs change their volume with every breath!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: The Heart
description: Get to know your heart and circulatory system!

items.title: Meet the heart!
items.description: Find out exactly where the heart rests in your body and what it does.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Two Circulations in the Body
items.description: Learn the difference between the pulmonary and systemic circulatory systems in the body.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Lub Dub
items.description: Ever wonder why the heart sounds the way that it does?  Opening and closing of heart valves makes the heart rhythm come alive with its lub dub beats...  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Layers of the Heart
items.description: Take a closer look at the heart, explore some of its interesting features and get to know the three layers that make up the heart.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Hypertension
description: Learn all about hypertension: symptoms, diagnosis, and how lifestyle changes can make a difference!

items.title: What is hypertension?
items.description: Learn the categories of hypertension for systolic and diastolic blood pressures.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Hypertension symptoms and categories
items.description: Learn the most common symptoms (or lack thereof!) and the two major categories of hypertension.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Hypertension effects on the blood vessels
items.description: Learn about how hypertension can cause damage to the large/middle sized arteries as well as the small arteries and arterioles.   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Hypertension effects on the heart
items.description: Learn 2 major heart problems that hypertension can cause.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: 4 lifestyle changes to help manage hypertension
items.description: Remember that a good diet, exercise, losing weight, and quitting smoking can lower blood pressure!   Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Lab Values and Concentrations
description: Ever wonder about your lab values and what they mean?  Lab values measure amounts of electrolytes or cells in your blood and occasionally tell you about how hormones and enzymes are working!  Dive deeper and get a good understanding of concentrations as well!

items.title: Introduction to lab values and normal ranges
items.description: Find out how health professionals use short-hand for labs and the meaning of normal ranges.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Units for common medical lab values
items.description: Figure out how to interpret the units in common medical labs including the CBC, Chem 10, and LFTs.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: What is an equivalent?
items.description: Figure out how to calculate an equivalent and how it relates to a mole.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Molarity vs. Molality
items.description: Learn how molarity and molality differ!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Molarity vs. Osmolarity
items.description: Learn about osmoles and figure out how to calculate osmolarity really easily.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Calculate your own osmolarity
items.description: Learn how to use three lab values (Sodium, glucose, and BUN) to approximate your plasma osmolarity.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Molarity, Molality, Osmolarity, Osmolality, and Tonicity - What's the difference?
items.description: See how each of these terms tells us something different about a solution.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Tonicity - comparing 2 solutions
items.description: Find out how tonicity is determined by ions that don't move across membranes and how it affects the movement of water.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Heart Disease and Stroke
description: Find out what can cause a heart disease and stroke, and how the two are related!

items.title: Heart Disease and Heart Attacks
items.description: Basics of heart disease, heart attacks, heart failure, angina, cardiac arrest.  Special thanks to Edward J Perper, MD for help in clarifying certain aspects of this video.  Licensed under CC-BY-SA

items.title: Thrombo-emboli and Thromboembolisms
items.description: Clarifying difference between a thrombus and an embolus (and between thrombosis and embolism)

items.title: Stenosis, ischemia and heart failure
items.description: Clarifying a bunch of medical terms around heart disease

items.title: Strokes
items.description: Basics of strokes

title: Heart Muscle Contraction
description: Find out more about heart muscles and what happens when they contract.

items.title: Three Types of Muscle
items.description: Find out what makes smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and skeletal muscle similar and different from one another.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Heart Cells Up Close!
items.description: Get a close-up view of the cardiac cells and see what makes them different from the other (skeletal and smooth) muscle cells.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Calcium Puts Myosin to Work
items.description: See exactly how Calcium binds Troponin-C and allows Myosin to do some work.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Sympathetic Nerves Affect Myosin Activity
items.description: Check out how the amount of Myosin that is tugging on your heart can change depending on your activity level! Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Why Doesn't the Heart Rip?
items.description: Understand LaPlace's law to see the effect that pressure, radius, and wall thickness each have on the "wall stress" in the left ventricle.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Heart Depolarization
description: Check out the flow of positive charge through the heart that happens every time your heart beats!  Learn how the heart is able to keep a regular rate and rhythm throughout your life.

items.title: Membrane Potentials - Part 1
items.description: Find out how a cell that is permeable to one ion can become charged (either positive or negative) if there is permeability and a concentration gradient.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Membrane Potentials - Part 2
items.description: Find out how a cell that is permeable to one ion can become charged (either positive or negative) if there is permeability and a concentration gradient.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Permeability and Membrane Potentials
items.description: Find out why a cell that is permeable to multiple ions has a membrane potential that is influenced by the ion with the highest permeability.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Action Potentials in Pacemaker Cells
items.description: Find out how the pacemaker cells use the movement of sodium, calcium, and potassium to get your heart beating!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Action Potentials in Cardiac Myocytes
items.description: See how muscle cells in the heart contract by allowing Calcium to flow inside and bringing along some positive charge with it!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Reseting Cardiac Concentration Gradients
items.description: Watch as the heart cells use energy to reset the concentration gradients for all of the ions after the action potential has gone through.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Electrical System of the Heart
items.description: See where the pacemaker cells start the electrical wave of depolarization, and how it gets all the way to the ventricles of the heart.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Depolarization Waves Flowing through the Heart
items.description: Get a clearer idea of what a "Depolarization Wave" means and how it goes from cell to cell through the entire heart!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: A Race to Keep Pace!
items.description: Find out how the various pacemaker cells in the heart actually race against the clock to try to keep pace for the heart, and how the heart has not one but two back up systems!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Thinking about Heartbeats
items.description: Find out what happens when things move very slowly through the AV Node!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: New Perspective on the Heart
items.description: Take a look at the heart in cross section, looking down at it from the top!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Nerve Regulation of the Heart
description: Learn how the sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves regulate your heart in so many different ways!

items.title: Changing the AV Node Delay - Chronotropic Effect
items.description: Find out exactly how your autonomic nervous system has a chronotropic effect (i.e. timing) that changes the delay between the contraction of the atria and the ventricles!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Changing the Heart Rate - Chronotropic Effect
items.description: Find out exactly how your autonomic nervous system has a chronotropic effect (i.e. timing) that changes speed of your heartbeat!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Increasing Ventricular Contractility - Inotropic effect
items.description: Find out how the sympathetic nerves increase the heart's force of contraction and speed of relaxation!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Autonomic Nervous System Effects on the Heart
items.description: Carefully go through each of the four major effects that the sympathetic and parasympathetic system has on your heart: Chronotropy, Dromotropy, Inotropy, and Lusitropy.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Getting a New Heart
items.description: Think through the result of getting a new heart, and how the heart can still maintain homeostasis when the nerves are no longer around.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Pressure Volume Loops
description: Watch as the pressure and amount of blood inside the left ventricle go up and down within fractions of a second!

items.title: Pressure in the Left Heart - Part 1
items.description: Watch the pressure in the left heart go up and down with every heart beat!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Pressure in the Left Heart - Part 2
items.description: Watch the pressure in the left heart go up and down with every heart beat!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Pressure in the Left Heart - Part 3
items.description: Watch the pressure in the left heart go up and down with every heart beat!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Left Ventricular Pressure vs. Time
items.description: Ever wonder exactly how the left ventricle's pressure changes over time?  Find out in this color-coded video!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Left Ventricular Volume vs. Time
items.description: Left ventricular volume changes over time in a way that makes a curious looking graph.  Learn more in this video!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Drawing a Pressure-Volume Loop
items.description: Use the left ventricular pressure and volume information to put together a cool new graph.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Understanding the Pressure-Volume Loop
items.description: Figure out how all of those physiology terms: end-systolic, end-diastolic, pulse pressure, stroke volume, and ejection fraction, can be easily figured out using the pressure-volume loop.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: End Diastolic Pressure-Volume Relationship (EDPVR)
items.description: Find out what happens when the left ventricle is not allowed to contract, and instead you simply add and take away blood from it.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: End Systolic Pressure-Volume Relationship (ESPVR)
items.description: Find out what happens when the left ventricle is not allowed to relax, and instead you simply add and take away blood from it.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Reimagine the Pressure Volume Relationship
items.description: Understand what is happening at the cellular level to cause two identical left ventricular volumes to have such different pressures!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: What is Preload?
items.description: Some say Preload = End-Diastolic Pressure, others say Preload = End-Diastolic Volume, so which one is it?  Watch and find out!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Changing the PV Loop
description: Find out how preload, afterload, and contractility work together to change your PV Loop (and affect stroke volume and cardiac output)!

items.title: What is afterload?
items.description: Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Increasing the Heart's Force of Contraction
items.description: Find out exactly how stretch increases force of contraction in end-diastole, whereas more calcium increased force of contraction in end-systole.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: What is Contractility?
items.description: Contractility tells us how many myosin heads are working at the end of systole; a number that goes up or down with the level of sympathetic nerve stimulation.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Getting Ea (Arterial Elastance) from the PV Loop
items.description: Find out how to use the PV loop to draw the Ea (Arterial Elastance) line, and what it represents.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Arterial Elastance (Ea) and Afterload
items.description: First, learn the difference between arterial elastance (Ea) and afterload.  Then, understand how Ea is affected by changes in afterload, and in turn, how the PV loop can shift.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Arterial Elastance (Ea) and Preload
items.description: Understand how Ea is affected by changes in preload, and in turn, how the PV loop can shift.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Stroke Work in PV Loops and Boxes
items.description: Watch how PV loops can be "morphed" into PV boxes to make drawing them and thinking about them much simpler.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Contractility, Ea, and Preload Effects on PV Boxes
items.description: See how contractility, Ea (arterial elastance), and preload each have an effect on PV Boxes.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Preload and Afterload
description: Find out exactly what preload and afterload mean, and why most of us use a handy shortcut to guess-timating what they are!

items.title: Preload and Pressure
items.description: Find out how left ventricular end-diastolic pressure helps you make an educated guess about preload.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Preload Stretches out the Heart Cells
items.description: Find out why stretching a heart cell in diastole affects how forcefully it contracts in systole.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Frank-Starling Mechanism
items.description: Carefully follow 5 different preload scenarios to see how each one will have a different effect on how actin and myosin line up.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Sarcomere length-tension relationship
items.description: Find out why the length of a sarcomere (in diastole) affects the amount of force that it can generate (in systole), and how that would look on a graph.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

items.title: Active contraction vs. passive recoil
items.description: Go through the similarities and differences between the sarcomere and a slingshot!  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: MIT+K12
description: Khan Academy is collaborating with MIT to develop videos on science and engineering projects. Through the MIT+K12 initiative, MIT students have created videos on hands-on projects, simulations and historic experiments. Enjoy!

items.title: Bridge Design and Destruction! (part 1)
items.description:
This is a two part video that introduces the different types of bridges. The bridge types will be introduced in historical order from simple (beam and arch) in the first video to more complex (truss and suspension) in the second video. This will show how bridges evolved as our designs and available materials expanded. The design of each bridge will be shown schematically along with the load distribution. The advantages and limitations of each type will be described. Video of actual bridges around Boston of the different types will be shown with the load distributions overlaid on freeze frames. Other iconic bridges will also be shown as still images with load distributions.  Technical concepts covered will be tension, compression, bending, span, force balances, material selection and beam/cable design. 

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at http://k12videos.mit.edu/terms-conditions

items.title: 2D Equilibrium -- Balancing Games
items.description: How does everything even out?  Learn what 2D Equilibrium is and how it effects the balance of life.

items.title: Shifts in Equilibrium
items.description:
Equilibrium occurs when the overall state of a system is constant. Equilibrium can be static (nothing in the system is changing), or dynamic (little parts of the system are changing, but overall the state isn't changing). In my video, I'll demonstrate systems in both types of equilibrium, and how the equilibrium states can be shifted. 

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at http://k12videos.mit.edu/terms-conditions

items.title: The Marangoni Effect: How to make a soap propelled boat!
items.description:
The differences of surface tension between soap and water can really make things go! This video shows some interesting demos illustrating the Marangoni Effect. Two liquids with different surface tensions will result in a surface tension gradient, resulting in a net force. This phenomena applies to each of the demonstrations shown. Watch a demonstration of how Marangoni stress can be used to propel small boats around (the "soap-powered boat").

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at http://k12videos.mit.edu/terms-conditions

items.title: 17. How to hotwire a digital camera
items.description:
This video shows you how to "hotwire" a digital camera. 

This video outlines the first step in making our digital camera work in the Bit-zee robot. The required voltage for the camera was determined by adding the1.5 volt AAA batteries (there are three of them) together to get 4.5 volts (because the batteries are wired in series). Since new batteries usually have a voltage that exceeds their marked rating the camera can easily run on the 5 volts that the center terminal of our L298 motor controller provides.

title: French Revolution
description:
"Let them eat cake!"  "No, how about we cut your head off instead!"  

The French Revolution was ugly, bloody and idealistic.  This tutorial covers the beginning of the end of the Bourbon rule (actually doesn't really go away for 60 years) and birth of France as a Republic (which will really take about 80 years).

title: Napoleon Bonaparte
description:
A man with such a huge "Napoleonic complex", that they named it after him.  A military genius with a ginormous ego, some people consider him a hero or a tyrant or both.

France has successfully overthrown Louis XVI in 1789.  It has gone through a many-year period of bloodshed and instability.  The monarch's of Europe are not happy about this "overthrow-your-king" business.  A 5'6'' Corsican establishes himself as a strong military tactician during the wars with other European powers and soon comes to power in France.

This tutorial covers the rise and fall of one of the most famous men in all of history: Napoleon Bonaparte (Napoleon I).

title: France's many revolutions and republics
description: Unlike the American Revolution which fairly cleanly transitioned the United States from British rule to a republic, France's process of democratization was much longer and more painful.  This tutorial gives a scaffold of that (and gives some context for the book/musical/movie "Les Miserables").

title: Haitian Revolution
description:
Yes, you are right. Haiti is not in Europe.  We put the tutorial here because it was a French colony and its own revolution is closely linked to that of France's.

Possibly one of the saddest histories that a nation can have, this tutorial tries to give as much context as possible for the birth of Haiti.

title: - 400 C.E. Ancient Cultures
description: Humans have been making art for tens of thousands of years, long before there was writing. Why was Egyptian art obsessed with death? Why did the ancient Greeks seek the perfect human form? How did the ancient Romans use art as state propaganda? Why was the naturalism of ancient Greek and Roman art abandoned with the rise of Christianity? This topic explores the art of the ancient world, from the Venus of Willendorf to a 6th-Century Chinese Bodhisattva.

title: Ancient Near East
description: Was writing invented to record poetry or great literature? Nope. Writing was invented to help keep track of beer and other goods and services! The ancient Sumerians were nothing if not practical. Ancient cultures established the first cities and large scale architecture. From the Gates of the City of Ancient Babylon, to the ancient code of laws instituted by King Hammurabi, the Ancient Near East is strangely distant but also remarkably familiar.

items.title: Introduction
items.description:
![The Euphrates River in 2005](http://khan.smarthistory.org/assets/images/images/Euphrates_River.jpg)

The Euphrates River in 2005

###The Cradle of Civilization
Mesopotamia, the area between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers (in modern day Iraq), is often referred to as the cradle of civilization because it is the first place where complex urban centers grew. The history of Mesopotamia, however, is inextricably tied to the greater region, which is comprised of the modern nations of Egypt, Iran, Syria, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon, the Gulf states and Turkey. We often refer to this region as the Near or Middle East. 

###What's in a Name?
Why is this region named this way? What is it in the middle of or near to? It is the proximity of these countries to the West (to Europe) that led this area to be termed "the near east." Ancient Near Eastern Art has long been part of the history of Western art, but history didn't have to be written this way. It is largely because of the West's interests in the Biblcial "Holy Land" that ancient Near Eastern materials have been be regarded as part of the Western canon of the history of art.  

###The Land of the Bible
An interest in finding the locations of cities mentioned in the Bible (such as Nineveh and Babylon) inspired the original English and French 19th century archaeological expeditions to the Near East. These sites were discovered and their excavations revealed to the world a style of art which had been lost.

Ancient Near Eastern art remains popular today; in 2007 a 2.25 inch high, early 3rd millennium limestone sculpture, the Guennol Lioness, was sold for 57.2 million dollars, the second most expensive piece of sculpture sold at that time.

###A Complex History
The history of the Ancient Near East is complex and the names of rulers and locations are often difficult to read, pronounce and spell. Moreover, this is a part of the world which today remains remote from the West culturally while political tensions have impeded mutual understanding. However, once you get a handle on the general geography of the area and its history, the art reveals itself as uniquely beautiful, intimate and fascinating in its complexity.  

###Geography and the Growth of Cities
Mesopotamia remains a region of stark geographical contrasts: vast deserts rimmed by rugged mountain ranges, punctuated by lush oases. Flowing through this topography are rivers and it was the irrigation systems that drew off the water from these rivers, specifically in southern Mesopotamia, that provided the support for the very early urban centers here.

The region lacks stone (for building), precious metals and timber. Historically, it has relied on the long-distance trade of its agricultural products to secure these materials. The large-scale irrigation systems and labor required for extensive farming was managed by a centralized authority. 

The early development of this authority, over large numbers of people in an urban center, is really what distinguishes Mesopotamia and gives it a special position in the history of Western culture. Here, for the first time, thanks to ample food and a strong administrative class, the West develops a very high level of craft specialization and artistic production.

Text by Dr. Senta German

items.title: Akkadian Art: Victory Stele of Naram-Sin
items.description:
Victory Stele of Naram-Sin, Akkadian, pink limestone, 2254-2218 B.C.E. (Louvre, Paris)

This monument depicts the Akkadian victory over the Lullubi Mountain people. In the12th century B.C.E., 1,000 years after it was originally made, the Elamite king, Shutruk-Nahhunte, attacked Babylon and, according to his later inscription, the stele was taken to Susa in what is now Iran.

A stele is a vertical stone monument or marker often inscribed with text or relief carving.

Speakers: Dr. Beth Harris and Dr. Steven Zucker
